item.comment:
The game marries beautifully about Cluedo, BSG, Mr. Jack, and Arkham Horror. You need to find the Chosen One (Cluedo) which is some kind of savior, but one of you might be the one to kill him/her (BSG), to find them you must pick a character and use their ability and move them (Mr. Jack) in various location on map and gathering clues to help you (Arkham Horror).
The bonus mechanic is also unique, and limited actions in total one game (not one round) makes it very different with any other game. Also, while it's semi-coop with traitor, there's only one winner. There's no all hero side win together. But strangely the mechanic doesn't make one player (that's not the traitor) try to sabotage the main goal. This is truly quite unique game.

item.name: The 15 Greatest Board Games in the World
item.comment: A gift from my friend, perfect for portable 2 player games, not really the greatest as the title said. Probably would if one of them really Agricola. But instead, all of them are abstract games.

item.name: 1830: Railways & Robber Barons
item.comment:
18XX is a series of train game about economic, and it has span out to it's own genre, separating from other games. While not the first game in line, 1830 clearly the trigger for the great many variants of 18XX family, a point of explosion in the history of train games.
The game puts you in the position of rail barons, the investor in train industry. There is stock market mechanism that really captures the fluctuating price of shares, and not by random. When the corporations operates, it will be run by the president (who has most of the shares), but will pay (or maybe not) the dividend, giving the investors in those corporations more money to buy other shares. At the end, as all economic games, who has the most wealth wins.
- An economical game about trains - Simulates really well about stock market and price changes - Quite realistic track making that gives satisfactory feeling at the end of the game. - Simulates progression of technologies by the trains availability and special rules, making a progressive gameplay. - Has many lots of opportunities for making clever play, either by stock manipulating or running the corporations. - No luck, all are player driven situations.
There is a beauty in thinking and player interaction. This game sums it well, and I mean really well. From managing into speculating stock, into the decisions of running the company, and at last the subtle negotiations. Beautifully elegant.
-----Remake of Mayfair is due, need to comment on that too, so far only played in PC and PBEM--------

item.name: 1844: Switzerland
item.comment:
This is one of the awesomely epic 18XX. There's a lot of different company to play here, lot of things to track, and lots of chrome. But not just chrome, the game could be maneuvered around it.
- Dynamic Priority deal and player turn - 7 different types of company (not just private and major) - Couple bonuses on run - Interesting train type (and rusting system) - Not really brutal stock trashing, but still possible to do. - Stock left in poll decrease price. - Must do highest revenue route.
This is clearly one of the heavier 18XX. Not for newbie 18XX indeed. There's too much decision path to be made, and lots of mistakes can be corrected if you do the right thing. But some of them are not obvious. 6-8 hours is clearly the correct time.

A sedate version of 18XX, slow paced, and focusing more on train and track building rather than stock market. It's a game where you really want to play the companies rather than stock manipulating. Probably the best 18XX from 1829 line.
Specialties: - No privates, but bidding for contract bond of making route of specific cities - 8 companies, some major, some minor - 2(3) different tracks that can be run by specific train - A lot of small town - 1D stock market - Selling or buying shares NEVER adjust price.

Rumored to be the best 18XX in 1830 branch, well, maybe at the time of release, but certainly not right now. But it's still a nice game. There are a lot of companies, so each player will at least get one. But it's true, player bankruptcy is a real risk! So it's brutal. The interesting thing is the ability to take loan and forming Canadian Government Railway. It makes the game fresh and so many dynamics.
Specialities: - 11 Companies - 1 of the Companies is the Government - Can take loans for the companies - Not fully capitalized, companies get money from selling shares - The requirement to float is different on each phase - Can upgrade or downgrade town.

item.name: 1860: Railways on the Isle of Wight
item.comment:
This game is brutal and full of bad choices. The most you can do is choose the least bad choice. Map is small, but the tiles are very restricting.
- Privates don't have special abilities - May ignore one blocked station - 1.5D Share prices - Running must be contiguous, and must touch the home base - Cannot buy the last train of a company - Different par value area - Can hold more than 60% - No limit at pool
This is a very brutal, competitive, unforgiving game.

Another great introductory game for 18XX series. This is almost as great as 18AL or maybe the same. It has more texture than 18AL, but with consequences of taking longer than 18AL.
It's probably also has fiercer nature than 18AL, but still more forgiving than 1830. And the rules is more closely to 1830 than 18AL.
Specialties: - Lots of private companies, with effect, exchange to shares, and block hex. - 7 companies, making it interesting for any number of players - The most similar of 1830 rules - Terrain heavy - Contested track tiles

item.name: 18AL
item.comment:
This is a great, if not perfect, introductory game for 18XX series. Not to mention there is a wonderful redesign by Koryo. There are couple additional rules compared with 1830, but mostly are minor. The great things about this game is everything is particularly balanced. You can start anywhere and stay competitive. So no newbie doomed for the entire game just because his first company was wrong.
What make this game perfect is that this game is tame enough for newbie, but still create chance for nasty play in stock or train buying by veteran. That's why it has great reply value, because there are so many strategies to explore. When you are tired of this (highly unlikely), I believe you've ready to move on to other 18XX titles.
Specialties: - Beautiful redesign - Print and Play - Balanced companies - Forgiving tiles - Mostly similar as the 1830 - Town doesn't count in running train - 4D trains to double the income - Early game can only buy one train per turn - Short bottom on stock market.

item.name: 18Ardennes
item.comment:
A fresh different 18XX. It has 1D stock prices, so it's on 1829 branch. But it's quite gamey in running the corporation. And I like the minor companies too. The downsides is the downtime. 1 OR is too long, because of the minor companies. Also, there are too many bonuses, while good, need a player aid, or it's easily forgotten. The 5 shares and 10 shares seems interesting, but quite useless in execution.
Specialties: - 15 minor companies without privates - Minor can merge into major, and assimilate - Many run bonuses - 1D stock market, and fixed 2 OR - Not fully capitalized, only by selling shares - Can convert from 5 shares to 10 shares. - 4D train is unlimited range, but can only get income from 4 cities, and doubled.

item.name: 18EU
item.comment:
This is probably one of my lowest rank of 18XX. The game has so much promises, yet fails in delivery. All the tension was when bidding Minor, but then the rest of the games feels flat and dry. The game protects you so much, unfortunately that means protecting your opponents too, making this uneventful game.
Specialities: - 15 Minors that can (must) merge to make Major companies - No different zones at stock market (2D) - Players cannot sell the shares before it operates - Tracks are very restricted - May split dividend
I give it twice (for maybe the 1st time is just wrong setup or something), but it didn't improve on 2nd play, so won't likely play again. The game is not too bad, but compared to lot others 18XX, so many titles to play, and so little time to play, making me probably won't play this game again.

item.name: 6 nimmt!
item.comment: A simple game about sorting number. Trying to put your cards without taking penalty. Oh well, pretty nice, but it's just a party game.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
This is a great light game about drafting, with civilization theme. But unlike fairy tale (which only set collection game), there's a great amount of mechanics in this game. Also, each player will have their own wonder (with different ability) making the game really flavorful.
The game itself is very tactical, with some degree of strategy. There's no winning strategy. You must be able to look at your opponents, and draft accordingly, whether try the strategy that they're not doing, or counter draft. Also, the game is quite easy to teach (if you're experienced teacher), and lots of fun, making it great game for gateway.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: This game is amazing. It has pretty cool mechanic. Tile laying, stock holding, and commodity speculation never been done so well. And if you savvy, predicting your other opponents could be fun too. Brilliant. Unfortunately, luck could be a little bit high. It's still manageable tough.

item.name: Advanced Civilization
item.comment:
This is the granddaddy of all Civilization games. Truly monster in game time alone. But the mechanics are a wonderful design. Truly breakthrough in new breed of gaming genre. Through the Ages may surpass it, but some of AdvCiv still has its own strength.
I've only played the PC game, so haven't tried it with other player, which I'm sure will be great!

item.name: Adventure of D
item.comment: I know it might seem harsh for fellow countryman, but unfortunately in and adventure game, I'm hoping to do some adventuring, beefing up my character, and probably do final, climatic battle. And that's where this game lacks. The final battle is anti-climatic, and has no relation whatsoever about your character growth. Anybody (as long as they pass the requirements) can kill it, provided enough luck.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: This is a nice, fast and tense game. The theme is thick in this one. It feels really you are exploring a temple, avoiding traps, while collecting treasure. The only grief is that the map only one, making its novelty easily wear off.

item.name: Age of Conan: The Strategy Board Game
item.comment: Conan has unusually strong mechanic and fun to play. The way to do battle and intrigue, the fate dice pool, every kingdom has their own cards, all is good. Sadly, all of this soiled by the presence of Conan (it should be good, but in this game, it breaks this game). The player who controls Conan gets a huge advantage, and if there are some Conan+Court dice at pool, most of the time it will be picked first. It makes Conan control is too big part of the game, and making the kingdoms more less just like furniture. Good at 1st play, but will be bored about it soon.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: Really almost has no connection with the computer game. But that doesn't mean it's bad. On the contrary, it's a great euro, but the theme of discovering new world is integrated well. On the other hand, the downside is too much focus on economy strategy. So, it's like no other strategy at all, whoever got to the best economy WILL win the game.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment:
Truly heavy brain burning game. This is Railroad Tycoon on steroids. A great game about train and delivering goods. It needs heavy foreplanning, and very unforgiving game. You could be entered into death spiral if you are not careful.
The great things about this game is how you plan your move and track building, into the last turn of delivering maximum length of route. The production part of the game really handled well by some luck, might affect your strategy if you are not prepared.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: Although the theme is quite tame, since I LOVE Harvest Moon Video game, so I kinda dig it. But the beauty of this game is the magnificent interaction of human to human and to mechanism. "You need to do this and before that do that after that will do those" kind of feeling is so strong here. And the theme is integrated so well, so you can't just suddenly re-theme Agricola. Not only that, the replayability is HIGH, because of the cards.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
item.comment: A very slimmed down version of agricola, many mechanics doesn't quite match the theme. And not a good game I think. It's still better to play 2p Agricola than this.

item.name: Alea Iacta Est
item.comment: Well, another take of euro dice game like Kingsburg. Not bad, but not great either. There's a place/slot that really makes it impossible to strategize. But overall, nice filler game.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: A nice game that a little bit underrated. There is a vicious gameplay behind that peaceful garish artwork. You need to monitor few different things, including your opponent. This is one kind of game where opponent matters more than luck.

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment: This is a light worker placement dice game. The rules are easy to teach, play fast, and there's quite handful special abilities to flavor the game. It's quite good to teach for newbies.

item.name: American Rails
item.comment:
This game derives heavily from Chicago Express. But it removes some of things that I dislike about Chicago Express and add some things that I really like.
- The turn order is variable, depends on your previous action. - Starting city of each company is variable, making more replayability options - Putting the income only at city making it more sense than Chicago Express. No more raising income with spreading to mountain without reaching the cities.
Overall feel, the game is more calculating and evaluation. This is where experienced players will usually have better decision than the less experienced. It's sign of a good game.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: It's dry. I don't mind some dry stuff as long as the mechanic is good. It is. Minus one very big mistake. Too random to formulate a strategy. It's very tactical, but while sometimes I don't mind tactical games, but the scoring nature is against tactical play, which I find counter-intuitive. I don't feel like I have any control in the game, so I hate it.

item.name: Android
item.comment: This game is great with the mechanic is so novel! It's truly masterpiece in design, so many interwoven things that hard to separate mechanics and theme (except the conspiracy, weakest mechanic-theme link). All in all, the theme is so great and drenched, by the time you finish, you would be drunk by cyberpunk noir detective situation. The only downside is the downtime between player, without clear possibilities to formulate strategy in other players turn.

item.name: Anima: Shadow of Omega
item.comment:
This is the game that I used to hate. The main problem I have about this game is ending condition. If all player play mean, than NOBODY will ever finish the game, unless he or she was super lucky. Then, why play this game? It's such a shame since this game has nice artwork and kinda cool rpg concept.
But the revised editions give nicely tweak of rule making the game really playable under reasonable hours.

item.name: Antiquity
item.comment: A beautiful game about building, managing resources, and hardship. Truly a beauty in game design the mechanic is so interwoven and makes you thinking very hard. This game rewards fore-planning so much that a wrong move could literally took you out of the game. Very unforgiving game.

item.name: The Ares Project
item.comment:
It's hard to describe the awesomeness of the game until you play all of them. All of those hype, and this game actually exceeds it. It manages to capture most of the feeling playing RTS (particularly Starcraft) without actually making it real time game.
Not only that, the asymmetry is delicious. All of the factions have a very distinct play style, and each of them can be played one way or another, depends on your strategy. And this game does reward skill and experience. There's lot of decision coming from your limited handsize, dual use nature of the cards, and to resource or not to resource.
If I may nitpick is the only need of screens. It simulates fog of war quite good, and I have no other solutions, but it's not cheater-proof. I don't play with cheater, but the idea of the possibility is bugging me a little.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment: My first Ameritrash, and soon fall in love. The way I could devise a story while playing is something that drawn me so much into this game. The feeling, the tension, the genius mechanism. Especially the frustration of hopeless situation, followed by improbable victories, giving real thrilling boardgame experience.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment:
In deck building games, this probably the less strategic of all. But also the best component and as fun as others. The idea to combine all card pool seems work. And it does make the game easier to setup and clean up.
Oh, and the theme is also pouring out in this game.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment: The premise is cool and the components are great. But the main problem is the downtime between players. In addition, there is no way to formulate strategy here. It's all tactical.

item.name: Aye, Dark Overlord!
item.comment: This is seriously a party game just for fun. What I don't like is the win or lose is determined totally by the one who become the dark overlord. Oh well, it's just for fun and all, but not to be played repeatedly.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: A nice party game, with the combination of shadow hunters and sitting duck element. Overall theme and fun are cool, but sometimes if with many players, it will be too long to wait for your turns. Luckily, it plays very fast, so the downtime won't be recognized much.

item.name: Batavia
item.comment: Hoping for economic game, only to find an abstract game. It's good though, but not my type. It also has nice artwork.

item.name: BattleLore
item.comment: This game is a nice compact and light fantasy wargame. Unfortunately the setup make it too much for what it gives. But anyway, it's a light game, toward more luck than tactics I guess.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment: I think the game really captures the film. The mechanics are great, but the player interaction is this game most potential talent. Constant suspicion, even though this is co-op game. Every mechanic is well thought and the possibilities for your friend is a traitor is superb.

item.name: Belfort
item.comment: The game has a very good mechanic, but awful scoring. Making it confusing views for me. It feels like the theme is good, but the end game is kinda meh. It lacks the feeling of epicness. There's no surprise getting from behind victory. Nevertheless, I enjoyed my time when playing it. So it's quite good.

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: Generally, I hate abstract (themeless) game. But I like to try something new, so at least I tried it. Don't get me wrong, the mechanism is quite good, but themless status will always drive me away. It's just me. Will only play if there are not other game in vicinity.

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager The Card Game
item.comment: Chaotic fun, but actually strategic. It has better luck controlling than I thought. It's quite good deckbuilding game, without falling to the conventional format. The only downside is the downtime with more players. Other than that, it's good.

item.name: Blue Moon
item.comment: A nice 2 player filler game. It's a solid CCG game, without collectibles element. A little bit too light for me.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: When I saw the video in Boardgamewithscott, I thought I would love this game. It's a game about construction of a city, with fantasy theme! Having played it, I'm not so sure. It's still genius in design, but the whole process seems a little bit abstract for me.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Concept is good, but the play kinda boring and too dragged on. You need to change your beans too much, giving no connection to the bean you planted and so giving you no sense of accomplishment.And it's too repetitive.

item.name: Brass
item.comment: A heavy thinking game with so many mechanism buried in it. Network building, industrial, technology research, and hand management. Overall it's a great industrial game. You need couple of plays to master the game. Experience really matters in this game.

item.name: Bruges
item.comment: Typical Feld, it combines many different mechanic and things to track. But somehow, unlike other games, it feels really luck dependent. Not the dice, but the cards, you really feel in the mercy of the cards.

item.name: Burn Rate
item.comment: This is a very light party game that is very nasty towards your opponents. Luck do play quite major here, as you expect on party games. Overall a nice "take that" game.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game
item.comment: This game is awful. The player isn't represented in any ways meaningful (what is the player? Character? Ancient One? What?). And unfortunately how to win the game is so dragging. There's no way to set up the game to be big bang later. You cannot play this fast, and with equal skill and deck, the game can stall very loooong time.

item.name: The Capitals
item.comment: Although a city building, the game feels like Civ game. With culture wars, tech race, population and public srvice tug of war, this game makes you think about your oponents condition every time. Really love to play again.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: More luck than H&G version, I prefer H&G

item.name: Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers
item.comment:
This is a heavy duty game in my gaming group, mainly because for it's easy and fast gameplay. Unfortunately another reason was because we didn't have many games back then. We've played it too often, that's why I got a little bit reluctant to play this again, but it still a good game.
After a while, this is probably still the best stand alone Carcassonne ever created

item.name: Carson City
item.comment: This is one of the games that good on paper, but eventually fail in execution. "A worker placement game with heavy western theme and high interaction!" really sound appealing. The theme starts strong on the setup, but turn to ambience during the game. And the interaction give hurt than good. Since the amount of die rolled here were small, a big unlucky (or lucky) roll can really change the game a lot. Doesn't mean it's a bad thing, but it makes Carson city falls on party game rather than strategy games.

item.name: A Castle for All Seasons
item.comment:
Pretty much combination of many mechanics. At first when I read the rules, it seemed blend pretty well. After playing it though, it's clunky. It's harder than any other game to see the immediate result of your action, thus forming strategy is more difficult.
Most of us after playing it didn't really know what could we do differently. I mean, we didn't really catch why we were lost, or worse, why we were winning.
It's not a bad game, especially the board is absolutely gorgeous. The rule are simpler than Caylus, but the strategy is harder to form than Caylus. Very not intuitive game.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: The game use dice, but heavy euro. It's no mistake if it's compared to Troyes. The mechanic is good, and the options of what you can do with your dice are more vast than Troyes. But, Troyes has better dice manipulation means, making it if you want a specific action, Troyes can do better than this.

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: A tile laying game with a little bit of auction, but the architecturing of the Castle was really pleasant.

item.name: Catan
item.comment: My first game that opened me to the world of Boardgaming. Right now, there are many better games than this, but this game will always remain nostalgic.

item.name: Cave Troll
item.comment: I had this game before. But when my love for area majority like El Grande diminishing, so does my love to this game. It plays almost like El Grande, but with more exciting theme. It's also a good mind exercise game. And nasty.

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment: Agricola, with semi dwarf fortress theme, making it a very delicious game. Most of the gameplay and many of the rules are derived from Agricola, but what I like are the abundant choices in this game. Agricola feels like a tight, agonizing decisions, while Caverna feels like confusing decisions of too many good options.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: The first great heavy euro game I've ever had. I will always want to play this game. The sheer number of strategy and move options will never run out even in many millenia. The language independence is one of the charm in the game. Everything has it's icon. Looking afar, it's one of the classic boardgame. One thing for sure, this is a nasty game. And the funny thing is, there are many good laugh from this game, even it's a brain melter game. Strange.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment: At first I was meh about this game. It's just another glorified area control. But after playing it, the theme was flowing like thick hot milk that I don't care anymore about the area control. This game is (super) awesome. The balance and the asymmetry are delicious. This game might simple at first, but there are so many subtle strategy and tactics inside, and the interactions is high. Other player actions will CLEARLY affect you.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment: A game about stock prediction and is a train game. Little bit different than 18XX game, since it plays so fast and on smaller scale. But it also has no luck and the game varies greatly by player actions. Means it can be sedate or nasty depends on the player.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: It's negotiation game to the essence, but without the bluff. Everybody can see what you have. There's no backstab, no tricks whatsoever. Makes this game very bland negotiations compared to I'm the boss, Junta, Cosmic Encounter, or Dune.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: It's a nice card game about figuring out your opponent. Though many explanations, this game is pretty easy for newbies.

item.name: Clash of Cultures
item.comment:
Elegant.
I rarely using that word, but that's what I describe for Clash of Cultures. It's the most accessible Civ game right now (the real Civ game, not lite-Civ like 7 Wonders or Roll Through the Ages). All the mechanics works beautifully one another, and very thematic. There are couple of things that kinda miss for me, making me cannot rate it 10 like others. But, coming from the genre that I love most, this is still a great game!
item.wishlistcomment: Will look for it until it has good publisher

item.name: Claustrophobia
item.comment:
2 Player Game
This game is on par with Space Hulk. While Space Hulk gives more tactical choices, Claustrophobia makes by with simplicity and randomized dungeon. The ability to handle damage is quite nice too.

item.name: Clue
item.comment: This is the basic deduction game. The best from the 3 mainstream game (the others are monopoly and risk). Nice to play deduction thing for a while.

item.name: Cockroach Salad
item.comment: This is a simple party game that about naming vegetables. It's really tongue twisting. Not a bad game, but won't likely play this again. Because, it's just party game.

item.name: Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! Russia 1941-42
item.comment: The game has a good mechanic which I see why many people drawn into this. I'm not a fan with WW2 theme, but I think I don't mind playing this. If only this was Sci-Fi or Fantasy game, I'll snatch this without any thought.

item.name: Container
item.comment:
This game is quite brain burning. And relies a lot on player interaction. You cannot play by yourself, since the only way to get goods to your harbor, you must buy form another player's factory. To have goods on your island, you must buy from another player's harber. It's a layer of layer of layer of production and purchasing.
Unfortunately, the scoring is based on set collection. But the beauty of the components, combined with the interesting logistics, makes up for it.

item.name: Copycat
item.comment: A combination of TTA, Agricola, and Dominion. That's really the gist of it. But surprisingly, the mechanic matches quite well. So far, it's good euro game.

item.name: Core Worlds
item.comment:
It's the best combination of RFTG and Dominion. You have cards that stay permanent in your area, but also doing some deckbuilding. Since the turns is limited, you won't shuffle a lot like Dominion, and your cards feels more meaningful. Also, with the sector system, the cards are progressively better, you're hardly screwed like in RFTG getting high cost card earlier, and cannot have your main purpose card later.
And the theme is quite apparent. Interaction is mediocre, but there's some tense on some occasion. It feels like Mage Knight by preparing your deck and army, to get better things.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment:
This is truly a game of negotiation. If you just want to play a game about diplomacy, this is the game. Simple enough to easily teach, and gametime is quite short so you don't feel dragged.
The elements for negotiation are a LOT of variable player powers, with the cards and some different effects, making it very high on dynamic and replayability. But it really needs correct group of player, or the game will be boring.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: My first play, that leaved quite a bad aftertaste. Too abstract, not exciting, I don't know what this game about. The component quite nice, but superfluous.

item.name: Crazy Kick
item.comment: A very light filler game with dexterity element. It's quite chaotic and nice. Not my forte but I don't mind play it sometimes.

item.name: Cuba
item.comment: This game has wonderful artwork. And it plays like puerto rico and caylus. A nice game on it's own, but It feels like just another euro.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment:
It has wonderful components!
And the simplicity of mechanics. But it seems a little bit too simple for my taste. This game prompts great many action options from the theme, but actually very limiting. So it feels like just another euro.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: Too long for what it gives. Also, what the hell is fantasy character without magic and leveling? I mean a real MAGIC! Not those sissy ranged attack replacements.

item.name: Diplomacy
item.comment: This is a strip down game to a pure diplomacy. The gameplay is simple, but to win it's really all about diplomacy. And of course, about BACKSTAB!

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment: Chaotic. Is the nature of the game. There's a lot of potential to kingmaking, since for leader bashing is not easy to do it by yourself. And since there's no basic actions, your plan could be unveil perfectly or destroyed mercilessly, just by the luck of the draw. Lot's of take that cards, makes this game is quite good as for fun game but not competitively.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment:
A party game. What can you say.
Actually, it seems the same like say anything. The game could be funny and silly, depends on the group playing. Doesn't matter. Won't likely play this anymore.

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment:
This game, is what Age of Empire should have been. As always, area majority is not one of my favorite mechanic, but that's only one of the mechanic. The other is worker placement which I love, and so many other little things. There are so many clever ways to play, so many little things to track by your brain. Experience will clearly helps you to guess/prevent/piggyback your opponent moves. Beautiful mechanism.
Unfortunately while the theme feels wonderful at first game, it becomes less recognized and more about mechanic. Since it's area majority, so mostly it's about move/remove pieces, and such. Opponents play WILL affect you, good or bad. Having said that, this game is really brain burning (a big plus for me!) and take quite long (doesn't matter for me). So while it's a good game, it's not for newbie for sure.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Very crispy crackers. That's what I call it. It fast, and light. Sometimes brutal, sometimes in abundance. So many things to be. The game manipulates deck building mechanic with power about... well, manipulating the mechanics. Seems too dry for my taste.

item.name: Dominion: Intrigue
item.comment: I admit it has more interesting cards and interaction. But I only rate it a little bit higher, and in the end, it falls to the same category with the original. Nice game, but nor so much with the theme.

item.name: Dominion: Seaside
item.comment: 2nd "variant" of Dominion that I play. In short, not really that interesting. It's a fresh take for Dominion since all the cards is new, but overall it has the same feeling of the dryness deckbuilding mechanic. Nonetheless, still a nice game to be played here and there :)

item.name: Dorn
item.comment:
When I read the rulebook and saw the components, I was afraid that the game was too simple, dry, deterministic, chess-like. I'm happy to find out that was wrong. Although the battle was deterministic, the game was full of theme. The hero, the monsters, all have their own twist and flavor. What a beautiful gameplay.
The only downside is the system is 1 vs many. System that I care less than even from co-op

item.name: Drakon (third edition)
item.comment: A good tile laying game, like Carcassonne. I could see it will be played quite heavily. Alas it's not mine, so I only get chance to play a few times. Good for a filler game.

item.name: Drum Roll
item.comment: It's a combination of worker placement and set collection. It's like Dominant Species all over again, in which the game is the combination of mechanic I love and hate. The game itself is quite good, but the theme is so-so for me (though integrated quite good). There's great deal of hard decision in this game.

item.name: Duck Dealer
item.comment: There you see a great combination game of Le Havre and Age of Steam. I like the deliveries and looking for the consumer, and I like the factories and converting different goods. It needs a great foreplanning and feels real good. Unfortunately, I think I like its predecessor more, Merchant of Venus.

item.name: Dune
item.comment:
Probably this is THE negotiation game I'm looking for. The premise of negotiation game is you need to have possibility to need help or helping other players, and so mechanically your move should be affected a lot by other player actions. It's pretty easy to fall on each end (Full diplomacy like Cosmic Encounter or, well, Diplomacy, or maybe full mechanical like Chicago Express or Container). But Dune strikes the perfect balance of mechanic and diplomacy.
Not to mention the special abilities of each faction is clearly bringing out the Dune theme a lot. Theme is dripping! The only downside is it's truly at its best at 6 player. Less is probably playable, but I don't know.

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment:
What a great game about Dungeon Lording. It's so thematic, but so brain burning and full of subtle interactions. A great game with satisfying feeling after playing it. The only downside is the game is not really on epic scale.
But that's for the base game. The expansion really helps out for the epicness

item.name: Dungeon Twister 2: Prison
item.comment:
2 Player Game
As the game has no luck at all (aside from the random of board, which is impartial), it's usually compared to chess. True, I had a feeling playing chess when play this, but unlike Navia Dratp, the themes overflow hugely. Very brain burning indeed

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment:
I was worried that having read so many reviews, this game will fall flat to me. Too generic tile, too generic enemies. But too my surprise, it holds quite few enough flavor to be tasty. Not super delicious, but tasty enough.
I don't know if it holds repeated play, but there's quite couple strategy to play here. Blindly forwarding will surely generate game over. So nice simple game, but not worthy for the price I think.

item.name: Dust
item.comment: A nice wargame. It has Risk feeling, but minus it's brokenness. You really could play nasty here. Sadly, the theme is a little bit pasted on. Unfortunately the game time is a little bit too long.

item.name: Earth Reborn
item.comment:
Finally, the miniature tactical gaming that are near perfect. I really loves deep complex game, and this game really offers a lot of aspects that you could do as persons in the game. But the greatest part is you can teach elements of the game modularly and step by step. So it's great for casual gamer, but also can deliver great game for hardcore gamer.
Usually I hate scenarios. Since in the game with scenario, I don't know which scenario should I use to "compare" my skills with opponents that are widely accepted as common full blown all aspects of the game. Well, in here, each scenario just a teaching tools, in which also its own good game, but the real deal is SAGS
Scenario Auto Generating System. How cool is that? You can build random map. Not only that, you can play up to 4 players too!! This will create infinite possibilities and replayability.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment:
Eclipse should be perfect in almost all aspect of 4x/Civ game. It has the exploration, tech researching, engine building, combat, and many things. Just tiny minor nitpick, it's [b]almost[/b] perfect.
Most of the game weigh heavily on combat. Half of the tech is around military, and basically instead military is one of the tools to win, in here military is THE tools to win. Doesn't mean this is a bad game, just not really what I expected in 4x/Civ game. The tech is not that interesting either, since most of it just better stats, not additional abilities.
But in the end, I can't deny that it's almost perfect game. So I'd love to play it always.

item.name: Elfenland
item.comment: The board is pretty that bring memories of childhood fairytale. It has unique gameplay abput exploring. I think children will love this.

item.name: Eminent Domain
item.comment: To compare this with Core Worlds is not really correct. They only share same theme and same year of release. But Eminent Domain relates more with RFTG (and somewhat Glory to Rome). Unfortunately the combos are quite simple, so it's not as deep as RFTG, which occupy more or less same gametime. So it's not really worthed.

item.name: The End of the Triumvirate
item.comment: The game modeled very loosely on Rome intrigue. In fact, there's almost no intrigue, just full blown conflict. It's somewhat balanced game, but very prone to kingmaking. I would always prefer full blown Republic of Rome than this.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: Though a little bit abstracted, this game is quite nice. Seems pretty balanced for various strategy, prompting for great replayability. It falls on light-medium euro, similar to Catan.

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: This is a nice filler game like dominion. But, instead building your deck, this is a game about drafting. And try to score as much point as possible. Unfortunately the game feels a little bit too generic. But overall quality is good.

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment: It's brutal and chaotic. Although you can make strategy about this, but the simplistic nature of the game makes it too dry for me. Also, the game feels really dragged on.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment: Party game about bluffing and bidding. Not my genre.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: It's a filler game about buying house and sell it again. What can I say?

item.name: Forge War
item.comment: This game was epic! It has resource gathering, engine building, (with adventurers and your market expansion) and quests! The theme is good enough, but the brain burning was really fantastic.

item.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
item.comment: Well, it's a Scotland Yard in upgrade. The game drenched in theme from Bram Stoker's Dracula, but only the environment, not the story. All characters, and everything here is very Draculaic and great. But when you play, the story doesn't really narrate much. It's still interesting in it's own right. The Dracula loves when the hunters are confused, and the Hunters love when the Dracula's cornered. It's a balanced I guess.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: It's awesomely fun and chaotic. Trying to build a good ship and then getting hammered is really satisfying.

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment: It's just roll and move game. No matter what choices you pick, it's all about your luck, and no decision could change that. I can see the appeal of theme for kids. For adult, not so much.

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: Overall it's a good game, and integration to the story is quite good. But the main gripe for me (and quite fatal) is the event card. Especially Mustering. I think I wouldn't have a problem if the events just some kind of outside force affecting your government. But not to be able to recruit people (even when you are rich) and need to wait the stupid event is just downright ridiculous.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment:
This game is surprisingly good. After my disappointment in AGoT the boardgame, this is a very joyful experience. So we still CAN play a decent game of thrones after all.
The gameplay is rich with strategy, tactics and theme. Luck is quite a minimum factor here (unlike the boardgame). Not to mention the customizable deck, but without the agony blind buy of TCG.

item.name: Genji
item.comment: This game is totally funny if you play with the right group. The feeling of wooing your opponent wives and seeing your own wive cheating throw us a lot of laugh. Unfortunately the component is horrible. It's still a good game though.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment: It's an average Co-op. I like this better than Pandemic, since it's prettier, and probably have more replayability.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: The theme is as usual medieval, but the game is nice euro engine building. With tile placement mechanic and somewhat variant of thebes's turn order mechanic, the game really shines with all its cohesiveness. The interactions is simply elegant. In addition of tile snatching, the game has built in interaction of scoring mechanic, in which we score the differences of with player who has the least in each category.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment: Wow, after finally getting it because I'm a victim of the buzz, I can say I'm not disappointed. This game is genius in design. I can confidently say this game packs as much strategies and combination to victory as Race for the Galaxy. Unfortunately it suffers from quite dull theme.

item.name: Go
item.comment: Probably the only abstract that I actually like. The rule are very simple, yet the strategy and tactics are so deep. Skill really make a BIG difference. No matter how much you've played, you will always learn something new. Total genius game.

item.name: GOSU
item.comment: A simple 2 player card game about battles. It's like playing MTG without instant and sorcery and enchantments and equipments. It's all about creatures, with various effect. Quite simple to teach, but the only gripe that I have is the Combat ability is the same for all creatures with the same level. More variable would be quite nice.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: El Grande has a very solid game design. At first, I like this game a lot. But the more I was exposed to other game, the less I want to play it. Main reason is its abstract and dull theme. Gameplay kinda repetitive. But I do know that this game is good brain burning game. And it's a nasty game, since people need to directly confront each other.

item.name: Ground Floor
item.comment: The game is so thematic. Every mechanic in this game make sense, making it easier to understand, and we can focus more on strategies. The game play is a very nice combination of action point selection and worker placement. And you do feel like a CEO.

item.name: Hamburgum
item.comment: Quite nice game about rondel mechanic. Good to play once for a while. It has resource management and area control. Feels' like just another euro I think.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment: Well, it's about trading. A light eurogame. There's not likely innovative mechanic. Just nice. It will get boring soon though.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment: A nice euro for a quick game. It's all about area control. But has interesting twist of technology researching. The theme is too dull to hold any interest.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment:
This is definitely another game beast. It's likely compared to Agricola just because the same designer. For me, Agricola to Le Havre is like Race for the Galaxy to Glory to Rome. Scarcity vs Abundance.
It's easier to explain the rules than Agricola, but has deeper strategy than Agricola.

item.name: Hawaii
item.comment: Build your own engine, action point allocation, and some resource management. It's quite unique game, but solid. Nothing can be complained about.

item.name: Here I Stand
item.comment:
The simulation during reformation period is really hit it all. Mechanically and thematically, it's perfect. And by the main mechanic to be CDG, it really brings out the dilemma of playing cards for conventional means or events. The asymmetry of each factions really brings out the theme. There are a lot of rules that covered almost all of things that happened during that time.
The downside is it's not really scaleable number of players, since all the factions need to be played. And I don't really dig historical theme, unless it's spanning across ages like Civilization.

item.name: I'm the Boss!
item.comment: Diplomacy on the roll!! This game is about backstabs, promises, treachery, and fragile loyalties. So great if you want to be mean to people. But, Cosmic Encounter would be better.

item.name: Ideology: The War of Ideas
item.comment: Okay, this is a great game. A game about spreading your influence like Twilight Struggle, but more than 2 players. And there are 3 kind of influence, and every ideology has their own power and weakness. Everything blended into a game of conflict with a lot of theme.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment: I had a really surprise playing this game. In a positive way of course. You are not controlling a country, you just hold shares in them. Like stock theme in Owner's choice. And the Rondel mechanic is wonderful. Unfortunately it's quite long for what it's worth.

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: I came with expectation of settlers pc game. And I was not disappointed. Balance between searching for gathering resources (and population), making buildings, and also trying to attack other people, combine that with different deck for each player (and many abilities), making it one of the best resources game I've ever played.

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: This game is awesome. You are pinched against player and the game system. This will really test your brain and planning. Great for gamers, probably bad for newbie due to its unforgiving nature.

item.name: Indonesia
item.comment:
The game of my country! How could I not love it??!!
Well, to tell the truth, it's not about the country. But the game mechanism is really good. As economic as 18XX games, but with very different mechanisms. A lot of planning, tactical and strategy, a little bit diplomacy and nastiness to other player, make this game very delicious.

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: This game is toned down version of Tigris and Euphrates. Sadly, T&E already quite abstract, and this game is pure abstract. I hate abstract, so I consider this game as the same as blokus.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment: The game really shines on finding your way of cool combos with your board and your hand. Due to the possibilities of heavy thinking, I will never play this again with 4 newbie player. 3 player is good, maybe 4 for all veteran player. The greatest satisfaction comes from executing very cool combos.

item.name: JAB: Realtime Boxing
item.comment: It's a filler game. It's a filler dexterity card game. Not that I hate it, it's just quick, fun, silly, and not really my forte

item.name: Jambo
item.comment: A 2 player economic game. It's kinda meh for me, I don't know why.

item.name: The Journeys of Paul
item.comment: The game is quite good for showing the hardships of making Christian community during the days of the disciples. An ok game, but the reference to the bible are good.

item.name: Junta
item.comment: As negotiation game, it's cool to see how your friends backstab each other, including you, whether as backstabber or backstabee. Unfortunately, it suffers from a simplicity of negotiation game into an unnecessary complex coup phase (which almost happens every turn), making something that should be quick game become long.

item.name: Kakerlakensuppe
item.comment: A little bit harder version of Kakerlakensalat, because of additional syllables. The components are different, in a sense. The pictures are totally different, but they are basically the same as Kakerlakensalat. You can play it with Kakerlakensalat rules and vice versa.

item.name: Kanban: Automotive Revolution
item.comment: Oooh boy, this game has so many interlocking things that trying to describe it is a great feat itself. There are ways to get resources (plans and parts) and spend them (upgrades or assembles) but also means to be more efficient on those areas (training track). and also small short term goal that will be scored. And while the theme is about car making, it has a very good ties with the mechanics.

item.name: Key Harvest
item.comment: A typical Euro with auction mechanism and tiling mechanism like acquire. It's a nice game, but just that. Not fulfilling or anything.

item.name: King of the Elves
item.comment: Some says it's better than Elfenland. Well, it's a good game, but I don't really like it.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: Tension. You will be pushed in every end of the year. There are healthy doses of strategy, tactics, and luck in this game. Good interaction, good tension. Nice game. The game is pretty too.

item.name: Kragmortha
item.comment: Well, this is zany and crazy party games with so many hilarious things. I cannot explain more except that if you play this, chaos is the word. Very funny, but not to be played many times.

item.name: Kung Fu Fighting
item.comment: Although this is a filler game, it's surprisingly fun. The theme is very thick, and many silly table talk. And very very vicious!

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment: It's a solid worker placement game, with some tweaks. The workers have different values, and also you can "kick" other players from the action spot. It's quite good, nice medium game.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment: Pretty Nice. Fun for quick versus co-op. A little bit too light for my taste.

item.name: Last Train to Wensleydale
item.comment: A little bit better than Steel Driver, quite involving mechanic. But also suffer the dryness of Martin Wallace. Oh well, quite an alright game.

item.name: Libert
item.comment: Well, what's to like? The theme doesn't get me, the mechanic is giant area majority (which I hate) with clunky inner mechanic, the artwork are minimum. Perhaps better with more players, but I'll play again only if I'm bored with other choices.

item.name: Lifeboat
item.comment: It's a werewolf/shadow hunter party like game. Not really my cup of tea.

item.name: Lifeboats
item.comment: This game is vicious. It's a diplomacy game where you need to took a vote for who would be thrown overboard. Quite a funny theme.

item.name: London
item.comment: The game takes a new twist about card combos. It's interesting building your cards for a while, and then run it altogether. And typical of Martin Wallace games, it's not abstract. There's quite a theme interwoven to the mechanics there, and it gives opportunity for clever play. I like it.

item.name: Long Shot
item.comment:
It's better than I expected. It's a great game with a good deal of choice, and good deal of luck. A good distribution for Ameritrash. I "might" give it higher rating if not because of the theme.
I hate horse racing. Nuff said.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: Although co-op is not one of my beloved genres, it's surprisingly better than I thought. They do have a good feel with the theme, if you want "alternate" adventure in Lord of the Rings world. Maybe not the best co-op, but certainly one of best.

item.name: Luna
item.comment: Feld is at it again. The theme is just tacked on, but the gameplay is very unique. It seems like worker placement, but also action point activation. There's quite a room for cunning play, so it's a good solid euro.

item.name: Macao
item.comment: This is a good game about tactical play. Strategy is there, but you must really setup yourself to be flexible about all. The feeling of pressure is delicious, and although its using dice, it's not about "high roller" wins scenario

item.name: Die Macher
item.comment: This game is so Great! The theme is kinda meh (what could you expect? Just political battle of German parties), but the mechanics are so great. No other game like it, the interwoven mechanics cannot be compared by other games. Truly brain burning and as nasty as politics.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment:
I always want fantasy adventure boardgame. But aside from Magic Realm, no game ever reach the "goodness" that I want. They're either too much luck or too simple. Of course there are some good fantasy dungeon game (like descent, claustrophobia), but what I want is more on adventure side. And then came Mage Knight.
- Randomized Map - Variable player power - Cunning play over luck (luck can be minimized a lot) - Units to command - Various skills, advances, and spell - Flavorful enemies, locations, and adventures. - So many scenarios to adjust playability
They answer almost everything I need. And the expansions make it better. This is a very heavy game. Not for boardgame newbie.

item.name: Magic Realm
item.comment:
This game is truly magnificent. Top of my list. Complex, but it has everything you could ever dream in Fantasy adventure boardgame. A holy grail, that no boardgame could ever replace since 1979!
Beware of the intimidating rules. Learning this by your own is a pain. It's easier if someone teach you, but learning by yourself is long hard road ahead.
And it's totally worth the pain, believe me. Legendary Treasure inside! A list you could do here:
- Different Character to play (with VERY different playstyle) - 1 to 16 players without ANY rule changes whatsoever. No change to setup, no special rules. - Players can join and quit the game anytime, without breaking the game. - Can play cooperative, competitive, or semi and backstab, without any additional rules. The game really made to encompass all of it in balance - Superb mechanics about damage and vulnerability (and weight) - Non HP character, and you get weaker when wounded (or fatiqued). - Controlled Luck - Great mechanics of combat which really simulates dungeon crawl combat. - Wide array of treasures and magic. And the differences is NEVER by stat number. Every treasures and magic has DIFFERENT effect. - Randomized setup for limitless replayability - Great mechanic on encounter/monsters. Still random, but you know what to expect. - Many victory conditions, combined with variable character, make the gameplay rich. - Horse to use as mule or stead. - Interactive NPC (can trade, fight, or even HIRE) - Everything is possible! Improbable maybe, but never impossible. - Unique way to cast magic and handle the cost. - Can incite war to different faction of NPCs - Optional rules for weather and level up.
So really, is there any element on fantasy adventure that is NOT in Magic Realm?

item.name: The Manhattan Project
item.comment: It's a twist from usual worker placement, but if you played many worker placement type, you'll pick this up easily. Can do direct conflict, and the bomb is the only VP, every other resources are moot. Not great, but not bad.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: The first boardgame I've owned (not including oldies like monopoly). I will never ever sorry for having this game. Until this time, it's still the best game to introduce to non-gamer people. Granted, for gamer person, this game is kinda dull and repetitive. But it's fun, and to this point, never fail bringing inner gamer from all non-gamer I know.

item.name: Manoeuvre
item.comment: It's kinda chess variant of Napoleonic battle. With some hand management. Well, it's nice quick 2 player game, but usually I'll prefer something else.

item.name: Marvel Heroes
item.comment: A mediocre game. But nothing stands out, mechanically speaking or thematically speaking. I like superheroes, and this game capture good sense of it, but not great. One thing that let me down is we play a band of superheroes, not just one.

item.name: Master Builder
item.comment: It has a good potential. I like the mechanism for building. But I hate the events. I don't mind random in games, but the events are too devastating, with no way to work around it. If you escape the events, it's just pure dumb luck. Nobody can prepare for the events to come.

item.name: Masters of Venice
item.comment: The game almost feels like 18XX game. There's a share price, and the price can go up or down depends on your actions. Also there's a different price for the product, so not only the share price. The only thing that makes this a lesser game is the luck (though not much, but 18XX has NO luck). But, the game makes a great use of blind bidding, simultaneous actions, stock market, and set collection (the only thing I'm not fond of).

item.name: MegaCorps
item.comment: After playing for a while the game fills a little bit too light for my taste. And you need very right group to make this game shine. But it's very thematic and full of negotiation.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: A fun light wargame. I could see some tactics and luck behind it. Will probably wonderful if it's fantasy. Oh, there is battlelore!

item.name: Merchant of Venus (second edition)
item.comment: A game where you must explore the vastness of the galaxy, meet new cultures, establishing trade route, become a space taxi, all while also upgrading your space ship. Not just by the theme alone this game captures me, but the way they handle luck (and how to mitigate it), and also multiple ways to score (money), make this game always a blast to play

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.comment: Ah, the glorious pirates, wonderful world of seafaring, combat and riches. All is built well in the game. From having manage your own ship, finding rumor, trading, and pirating, the theme really evokes well. Unfortunately the gameplay hinders me. See, I like controlled luck, that is, you can modify your rolls or something. There's some degree modification in this game, but not enough to say "controlled". A pity, since other than that, I love the other aspect of the game.

item.name: The Mines of Zavandor
item.comment: A nice gateway for engine building. It's simple to teach, yet quite variable to play. The main mechanic is closed auctions with engine building. Good to play casually.

item.name: Mission: Red Planet
item.comment: A combination of El Grande and Citadels, with better theme (Steampunk Fantasy).

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment: A game of auction where player bidding for painting, with one problem. The painting is crappy. Seriously, this is quite descent game buried under ugly components. The game of auction is nice, highly interactive with other players. But, for me it's kinda so-so games. Maybe because I've played too often?

item.name: Monopoly
item.comment: I have to admit, when I was a kid, I like this game. But I believe that's because NO OTHER GAME beside this, at least in my country. All luck and nearly no decision are what make this game so bad, that I will never play this again.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: Nice 2 player game, with some luck but not crucial. The most defining thing is your mind battle, with deduction as your sword and shields.

item.name: Mr. Jack in New York
item.comment: Essentially it's the same Mr. Jack, just with different twist of map and player abilities. Since I don't like the first, I don't like this either.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: I thought Munchkin was a bad game based on many people said. Upon playing it, I had quite fun. Not for the competitive one, just play it like party game and it will be so much better.

item.name: Mystery Express
item.comment: Deduction galore. The premise is good, but it fails kinda flat. The problem lies in the impossible to deduct all the element (or if possible, probably due to high luck). So, not really the deduction I hope for.

item.name: Navegador
item.comment: The game is good, and the rondel works. Although, I don't really necessary see that using different mechanic could be less interesting. Quite brain burning, but you need other people to prosper. A medium euro at best.

item.name: Navia Dratp
item.comment: The figures and artwork and components are gorgeous. FFG or other AT publishers should follow these examples, not just continue making unproportional miniatures shape. Unfortunately, it's a chess variant, which I hate.

item.name: Nefertiti
item.comment:
The whole point of this game is Set Collection, which is one of the mechanics that I hate. So I wouldn't likely play this again ever.
The only saving grace is the bidding mechanism. It's quite fresh and gamey, interesting. But other than that, this is a simple game.

item.name: New World: A Carcassonne Game
item.comment: It's like original Carcassonne, only better. Most of the scoring mechanisms are similar with Carcassonne, but with some additional options and bonuses. There would be no reason to buy the original unless you want to buy ALL of the expansions.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: A nice light sci-fi wargame. I think this is what Starcraft supposed to be. Build army, try to get resources from mine, and build more army. A nice and quick game for a conflict game.

item.name: Nightfall
item.comment:
Nightfall gives a little twist about deckbuilding. It's certainly the most different from all other deckbuilding. The way to play cards (chaining), buying (claiming) and the cleanup (not discard all of your hands) to the final score (having the LEAST of "VP thing").
One problem is, the way to give someone wounds (-1VP) is to attack them. It's nice to be interactive, but with this system is VERY prone to kingmaking. No matter how good your deck is, as long as you're targeted, then you're history.

item.name: Ora et Labora
item.comment:
Wow, that's all I can say after playing this. It's a resource management galore, on steroids. It reminds me of The Settlers (PC game, not Catan), and I really love that game where you can process goods from grain to flour to bread to food for worker to build other buildings, and other resources that have their own path. There's almost nothing that I dislike about this game (the player boards is okay, not bad)
The only gripe is the name, or to some extent, the theme. I don't see why it needs to be about clergymen, since you could retheme it into normal medieval village trying to grow and I would dig it better. During my first time playing I keep wondering where is the "religion" theme in this game, and at the end it's none.

item.name: Owner's Choice
item.comment: A nice fast paced stock market game. The theme and mechanism are quite innovative. First glance at the board will correlate people to monopoly. But the gameplay is as different as north and south. And it does capture the need to smartly organize your stock. Unfortunately, it's too simple for my taste.

item.name: Pacific Typhoon
item.comment: I don't like WWII theme that's for sure. But the mechanics make me like just playing cards. I could be alliance or Japan and it won't matter. No connection to the theme.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: It's great and brilliant co-op game. At first. But after several play, it fell flat and dry. And there's still one player control problem.

item.name: Patchistory
item.comment: Although a Civ game, the main component was tile laying game. I don't know how to describe it, but it just feels something is lacking. And it's as long as other civ games, so that's not a plus point for tile laying game.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords Base Set
item.comment: It's quick, bite sized adventure for a session, but turning into a great meal when played as campaign for multiple session. It's somewhat scratch the itch of playing RPG in terms of customizing characters, but also the simplicity of the mechanics help the story progress easier than traditional RPG.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: Nice worker placement game. And it plays almost like Caylus. While it's not as sophisticated like Caylus, the theme grasp this game strongly. That's what I like about pillars. Not to mention the wonderful artwork.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment: It's a pure economic game, where you need to buy, produce, and sell things, and your vp is money. It adds some layer on producing, so it's not the game about buy low sell high, but the market volatile too much from other players, making it too hard to predict.

item.name: Pocket Civ
item.comment:
This is a good game! Even though it's solitaire, but I was surprised by the amount of decision need to be made for this kind of game. Quite mind exercise, but the randomization make the game tense and fun.
The amount of details in events and civilization advances I think already make this game eligible for a full civilization game, not just civ lite. Perhaps the time needed, the pocket-sized game, and solo play, make this civ-lite, but the contents are definitely not!

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: A great euro game. It truly scratch your calculating ability to the max. It's a game about economic slowball building, with theme of power plant companies. You can auction the power plant, buy the resource which get more expensive as demand increases, and build network of electricity.

item.name: Power Grid: The First Sparks
item.comment: The game borrows heavily from Power Grid. It's nicer, more compact, faster, but stay deep. It's easier to bring in newbies, and not that mathy. Time will tell if this has same replayability.

item.name: Prince of Chaos: Battle for Tae Orn
item.comment:
This is truly a great fantasy wargame. Not just light wargame, but heavy wargame. Almost everything is factored here. Even PC games don't have this kind of level of detail, except few titles like Total War series.
If you want realism, need to try wargame, but like me, hates modern or historical battle, then this is the game for you. The only problem for the game is the slow pace.

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment: At last I tried this "Multiplayer Solitaire" legend. Well, it does seem lack of interaction, but to say none would be understatement. The game itself is actually good. Nice to play once in a while

item.name: Progress: Evolution of Technology
item.comment: The game feels like a good civ game at the beginning, unfortunately it gets dragged near the end game. Also it's quite multiplayer solitaire, and you can't really form your strategy, just do with what you have. I still quite like it because of the theme.

item.name: Prophecy
item.comment: This is a nice fantasy adventure game. It has everything, combat, magic, classes (not really many differences), and encounter. Fun to play with shortened version only. Playing full game is like asking for slow death because of the repetitiveness. Also, luck plays a major role here. A LOT!

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Puerto Rico was my first complex game. And there I found my love about fiddly things. After playing so many times in excel, the desire is a little bit diminishing. But it's a solid game, and I won't turn down a challenge to this little brain exercise.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: Surprisingly, I like this a little bit more than Dominion. Maybe because the dryness of Dominion, and the tense created when you roll the dice. The variable setup is quite nice too. Unfortunately, because the nature of the dice, it's also harder to form strategy here, making me cannot score it higher.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: This is a game that usually compared with Modern Art. This game is all about action, and having playing it, I'm surprised that this game gives very different feeling about auction. I still prefer Modern Art though.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
All I can say is Wow! This game truly great with so many possibilities, strategy and tactical. The mechanic interaction is so dynamic, make many interesting replayabilities. But the learning curve is pretty steep. After you pass it and everything clicks, you will see a whole new world!!!!
Unfortunately, the expansion is stretched out a little bit too much. Making the game too random for what it's worth.

item.name: Railroad Barons
item.comment:
All in all, it's a great 18XX for 2 player game. It lacks of route building of course, but compacted more into company (holding in this game) port folio (like any 1825 branch) and train (railroad in this game) management. And like any other 18XX, there's a great deal of learning curve to understand the strategy.
- 1D stock market - No route, just fixed revenue - Interesting bidding of privates (Investor in this game) - Unusual shares certificate - Many optional train.

item.name: Railways of Europe
item.comment: If only this game is not an expansion but a stand alone game, this would be great. Alas, that's not so. Oh well, the game plays very much like Railroad Tycoon with different map and cards. And also some bonuses. I like the map better than the original.

item.name: Railways of the World
item.comment: It's a nice game for gateway to the train games. The components are superb, and the gameplay easy to catch but still gives room to good strategy.

item.name: Rattus
item.comment: The tuned-down version of El Grande. I might like it, but unfortunately I don't like El Grande, so, that's not saying much. The bad part is the end game, it feels so artificial.

item.name: The Republic of Rome
item.comment:
A brilliant game! Really captures and simulates nearly everything from the birth of Rome until its decline. The rulebook makes it harder to learn than it is. It's really a great game with natural flow if you know all the rules.
The best part of this game is the negotiation. This game takes best part of gamey and negotiation, making it seems like Cosmic Encounter with many other things to do. As always, gametime might be a long, but what can you say for epic and perfect game. Unfortunately the theme is Classical Rome.

item.name: Resident Evil Deck Building Game
item.comment:
At first I thought it resembles Thunderstone, but after playing it, I think it's more familiar to Dominion. The card effect bearing little to the theme, so it's kinda dry. After couple of plays it's just about the mechanic.
It's quite a good game actually. You could still play it with strategy (remember, more Dominion like), and the VP card won't clutter your deck (more leeway deckbuilding, and easier to score). But it has push your luck element too.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment: This game is Battlestar Galactica distilled into its very essence. There's a traitor in us, and you must try to win couple of missions. It's fun and light game, perfect as a paranoia filler.

item.name: The Resistance: Avalon
item.comment: A party game that's way better than the Resistance itself, since some of the tweaks balances the game better. Perhaps, this could take over party game spot in me from Werewolf.

item.name: Restaurant Row
item.comment: This is quite a good game actually. It covers a lot about restaurant business, I love special powers of staffs and renovations. The theme that built into mechanic is quite complex. But unfortunately it suffers from a great randomization that we have no means to control, making it just a simple fun game instead good strategic game. What a shame.

item.name: Rex: Final Days of an Empire
item.comment:
Comparison with Dune is inevitable. But for me, Rex has better rules, better clarification, and better gameplay experience overall. It's shrewd negotiation and cunning play packed into one solid game. The only thing that I miss is the ability to bribe other players anytime.
I could see why Dune veterans will still love Dune better. If you have played Dune 20+ times, and will continue to do so with frequency about 10 times each year, I believe you will like Dune better. But for limited experience with Dune, and won't play that many, Rex is better.

item.name: Rialto
item.comment: Like any Feld designs, it covers some combinations of mechanics, and interestingly entwine. Although, as usual, I really dislike area majority, and this game focus on it, so I cannot give this game too many value.

item.name: Rise of Empires
item.comment:
It's the combination of Caylus and El Grande. The action selection part is kinda cool. Make you need to think at least 1 turn ahead. But the area majority is very thick here. And I hate that.
And the theme is very thin.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment:
It's a heavy brain burning game about logistics and processing. Not only you need to care about which item will be processed into which item, but also the transportation and network for ease process. A lot of foreplanning indeed in this game.
Unfortunately the goal is pretty much the same. The difficulty lies on to calculate the turn, and where should you stop, gold, coin, go for stock exchange. If only there is another way to win, it would be better.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: A delicious game. It means that the themes are dripping so much it covers all the mechanics. Or is it the other way around? Anyway, being a castaway, and building for your survival and skills always fascinates me (in game, not real life!). And this game quite capture that feeling. Shame it's only co-op

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment: A little bit heavier and more strategic than its counterparts (Race for the Galaxy). Strange, since usually with dice everything seems to be more "casual", but not this one. It feels more thematic, more strategic, and somehow more fulfilling.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: Truly a light Civilization game. Actually, it's a dice game, but with a combination of managing empire and development. Plays very fast.

item.name: Romance of the Three Kingdoms Card Game
item.comment:
I like ROTK theme. It's a heroic story with politics and development. This game almost nailed it. But miss with very fatal flaw. There is no development or resources. Just land grabbing with your generals and that's it.
And the biggest flaw is combat. Essentially it's just rock-paper-scissors. If you lose, you die. Even it's Lu Bu against some peasant. If tie, only then you will compare the combat power. So silly. No soldier number. Just rock-paper-scissors.
The artworks are quite nice artistic though.

item.name: Rune Age
item.comment: Best deck building game so far. Yes it's lack variety, but the gameplay really captures the essence of Runewars. You have your own selection if units, attacking cities, gaining neutral allies and tactics, and couple objectives. The theme is really great.

item.name: Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment: This was my first fantasy adventure boardgame. I have a quest to find greatest Fantasy boardgame ever, and sadly this game far from it. Downtime is too much, and no spells. NO SPELLS. What kind of fantasy is that? And it's too repetitive. Kill, upgrade, kill. But it does capture a little bit about fantasy adventure, so I'm intrigued to play if the mood strikes it.

item.name: Runewars
item.comment: Another great game with scale almost like TI3. It has resource management, Army, role/action selection. Many jockeying on mechanic but still having great portion of theme. As like TI3, the base game has some flaws, but maybe it will be eliminated by expansions.

item.name: Russian Railroads
item.comment: The theme about railroad is almost non-existent. But the gameplay is good. You need to balance from many progress tracks, and worker placement is always welcome for me.

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: Simple Co-op with traitor card game. There are lots of better games.

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment: So abstract. No mechanic represents anything or theme. Fortunately, the mechanism is interesting, I could still like it. And the artwork is horribly ugly. Functional, but ugly. Oh, and very prone to AP.

item.name: Sator Arepo Tenet Opera Rotas
item.comment: I couldn't describe it too much. The mechanic is so novel so I can't compare it to anything else. But it's great. Puzzle combined with "magic" and such. Nice game.

item.name: Say Anything
item.comment: It's a fun party game where you could literally say anything. It's a great tool for socializing. But for party game, I prefer werewolf.

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: This game is wonderful economic game, with Fantasy theme! What more could I ask? Apparently, game-time. It will take some time (maybe 2-3 hours), because so many calculations to be made (like power grid). But that doesn't mean repetitive, far from it. Instead every turn you will progress to be better. And the tension battle of auctions really makes it strategical yet also tactical.

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment: It has some good qualities, but it doesn't get much. I think I would prefer Fury of Dracula than this. Their tracking mechanic is basically the same.

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: Simple and captivating gameplay, yet it's not for newbie, since the card effects can produce some good combo. It's an engine building game with some level of take that cards. Good game, reminds me of Race for The Galaxy

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment: For Co-op game, this is not bad. But for a game itself, it suffers from wild swings of luck. From the mechanic on the rulebook it seems there's a lot of room for clever plays. Unfortunately during the game, it actually doesn't matter that much. Yes, you can do stupid things, that's definitely path to failure. But you can do average thing and still win, or you can do your best thinking and still lose.

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment: Nice party game, like werewolf. But every person has their own roles, so they won't sit idly like villagers in werewolf. On the other hand, each player has their own turn, so if playing with lot of people you will experience some downtime.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
