item.comment: I must admit, I was drawn by pretty bits and rich theme. But, it's not as fun as Arkham Horror. Although it's kinda fun a game world in Arthurian legend, I couldn't help feel a little bit empty when playing it. Unlike Arkham where you need to do couple of things to close the gate or something, in here, to progress basically you just discard a card. It's the adventure feeling that lack, not to mention the release of Battlestar Galactica, which is better in EVERY regards.

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment: This is the proof where sheep could be evil. DO NOT fall into their cuteness, this game is totally nasty. You have to play as mean as possible to your opponents, as they try to do the same to you. And this game is quite high brain burner. Doesn't mean it's bad though.

item.name: Shipyard
item.comment: The game has a lot of things to track, and it's really good economic game with ship building. You really feels build ship parts, components, and crews. My only gripe is that how to get money, is by railroad car, and it's really feels detached than the entire theme of everything else

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: This game is probably the closest game of Romance of Three kingdoms (PC game) converted to boardgame. It has some area control, majority, and first of all, programmed action. The game is quite nice with some limited situations (you can't war with all), so it takes some cunning to play. But, the danger of kingmaking lurking greatly here.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
item.comment:
This is a wonderful game about civilization. The quality of components is beautiful like usual FFG standard, with some of the arts come from Civ V the PC game. It really captures the gameplay of Sid Meier Civilization (in PC), with some of it are streamlined for boardgame. There are:
- City outskirts (and resources around it) - Buildings - Modular map - Tech Pyramid (brilliant idea!!) - Wonders - Great People - Asymmetry player (civ) power - Multiple winning conditions - Some luck, but easily mitigated with good play
All of the 4x (Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate) are presented here. Although it bears the same theme with Through the Ages, surprisingly it's very different. SM Civ focuses on parts where Through the Ages only touch it lightly. It's clearly a great game.
Also, this is rare for FFG, but the base game is completely balanced! There is really no need for expansions, except for more culture cards and civilization choices (Errata and FAQ's still needed though). But that's minor.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Boardgame
item.comment:
At first I thought this game would be awful, based on everybody reviews about this game. After playing it, it exceeded my expectation. Though mechanic-wise it's inferior than Through the Ages, it's still well designed (but not well tested). I had an epic feeling when playing it, and sure it was fun. The downside is it was really long.
The component and artwork needed some mention too. The quality of miniature are pretty good. And the artwork is genius. Many puzzles and stories behind every work of the artist.

item.name: Sitting Ducks Gallery
item.comment: A very light game, just for party and fun and filler. Good for a short laugh game.

item.name: Skirmish Wars: Advance Tactics
item.comment: It's not a bad tactical game per se, but not great either. The game got nicely wide array of units, but unfortunately the difference is not that great (only power and movement). Not really textured. The special ability doesn't do any much game effect. Seems like wasted potential.

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
It's a world of slaughter, a world of tears It's a world of kill, it's a world of fear There's so much that we share That it's time we decline It's a small world after all
It's a small world after all It's a small world after all It's a small world after all It's a small, small world

item.name: Small World Underground
item.comment: Well, it's a Small World afterall. My feelings for this is exactly the same like with original Small World, only the power and races has different abilities. And also few additional gimmicks. Other than that, it's essentially the same game.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: Very chaotic and too fast. So little that players can do (quantity of actions, not variety), and so little that players could accomplish. They just... survive. Unlike other co-op games where we could reach some specific goals.

item.name: Space Bastards
item.comment: Space Bastards has quite interesting mechanism. Simultaneous action selection mechanism, combined with variable relationship between aliens, so during a game one kind of alien could be very powerful but weak during other games. Unfortunately it's quite chaotic, and prone to AP. I'm fine with one of them but dislike both in the same game. Because it's chaotic you cannot plan that much further, resulting you have nothing to do during your opponents turn.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment: Whoa, this game is so unique. It's nice engine building with realtime aspects there. No turns, just the timer with sandtimer. It's quite good mechanic. But since no turns, everybody just watch their own progress. Interactivity with other players is usually less efficient. So unfortunate.

item.name: Space Hulk (third edition)
item.comment:
2 Player Game
It's fast paced, tense, and gory! I love it when the game is this brutal, but not chaotic. Luck certainly play part in this, but not dominating. A sign for a good game.
And the gorgeous miniatures! Who could resist them?

item.name: The Speicherstadt
item.comment: This is just another bidding-set collection euro. Nothing really special about this, a very passable games.

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game
item.comment: A wonderful space dogfight in Star Wars universe. If that theme doesn't already attract you, the gameplay also quite good. The basic gameplay is very simple rules of movement and shooting, but high tactical and spatial skills are needed to win the game. Not only that, you can customize your ship (pilots and upgrades) and also your army composition. Definitely a blast to play

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment:
A great sci-fi game. I love StarCraft in PC, but please don't really compare it to the boardgame version. It has different feeling and mechanism, it's a brave move from FFG and I think it's a good move. Rather than try to be exact like the PC game as possible, they made a good playable space wargame. There is development and research, battle of armies, and area controlling. And the components are pretty.
When you get familiar with the faction's ability and mechanics, this become quite cool subgame of cunning play. The only downside is all of them are geared towards military (It's Starcraft after all).

item.name: Steam
item.comment: I don't really like this game. Particularly because it feels very so-so. To get new player into train games you have Railroad Tycoon that focus on pretty bits and fun. And for heavy gamer you have Age of Steam for brain burning. This falls pretty meh in between.

item.name: Steel Driver
item.comment: Pretty bla and meh. Strike me as odd game that doesn't belong to anything. For easier and more thrilling game you got Owner's Choice, and for heavier you got Imperial.

item.name: Stephensons Rocket
item.comment: It's not really that bad, but the main scoring comes from set collection, which I hate. It feels like Acquire got little upgrade

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: It's quite fun. This is really the Caylus lite. With some dice and lesser rules, fun to play when you don't want to melt your brain. And don't forget the gorgeous components that will draw you into the game.

item.name: Strasbourg
item.comment: I really don't know what I like about this game. But I do like it. It's pretty much themeless, but the mechanic is really ingenious. It combines long term strategy and tactical very well, and the need for ability to read the situations and read your opponents move, hooks me for this game.

item.name: Stronghold
item.comment:
2 Player Game.
At first when I read the rules, it seems bland and dry. Sure it simulates a complex game of siege, but it seems so generic. After reading new rules with little thematic background, it improves a little. But when I played it, it feels so good. When we are familiar with all of the actions there, the game will play fast, and it is a good game for 2 player.
I consider this a lot with War of the Ring. After some thinking, I think war of the ring suffers from long setup, although it's comparable with the epicness. But for 2 player game, I think this is better compactness.

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment: A simple tile laying and buying game, with positional placing to improve (or decrease) your income or points. And also has hidden shared end game goals. That's it.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment: Nice tactical game, but not too great I think. The abilities doesn't really get me in the 'epic' feeling, and the game seems lack of real depth.

item.name: Super Dungeon Explore
item.comment: Gameplay is quite simple, so it's easy for new players to come in. I don't really like 1 vs many, so the score kinda reflect that. But my main gripe is there are too little of content from the base game. This game need to expand a LOT! The base game only would do well for less than 5 plays, after that it's quite stale.

item.name: Sylla
item.comment: It's a game of... I don't know it's a game of what. Thematically, it's about ancient rome. Mechnically it's somewhat thematic but also feel some kind of mish-mash. Don't have the feeling to hate it nor wanting to play again. A so-so game.

item.name: Takara Island
item.comment: The game is simple push your luck game, with slightly nice artwork and theme. But for a simple game, it takes too long to finish

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment: Gorgeouse compenents, that's the first impression. Not bad, that's the second impression. For a light gateway game, the rule are simple enough to understand, and there's still room for luck and good plays. Nice game.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment: Immersions! is what this game about. You really will be brought to the fantasy world of Arabian nights. A great game for storytelling, and not going for competition.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment:
Civilization is a genre created by game called Civilization. But to this date it's still unclear whether the boardgame or the PC game (by Sid Meier) is the trigger of the genre. It doesn't really matter anyway, since the elements inside are things that make this genre great.
- Span of ages in time, from primitive to modern. - Different technologies to research, giving many abilities - Different civilizations, giving each player different powers - Explore the world and use it resources - Managing population, happiness, and other resources to successful civilizations - Complex gameplay
Those all the great aspects of Civilization game. And to some extend, Through the Ages nearly captures it all. Sid Meier should be proud, since it's inspired by the PC game more than the boardgame. Great game, great mechanics, all together in one. The randomized setup and how things are available game make it very high replayability. Luck has some part here, but ultimately the decision is the one that make or break the victory. A perfect situation for controlled luck. Combined with there are so many path to victory, I can say this game is perfect.

item.name: Thunderstone
item.comment: I truly grateful to Dominion for ushering a new gameplay in boardgame, although it's just a bland barebone. But because of that, there is now a Thunderstone, with rich thematic feeling and great gameplay. It really captures the adventure part of the game and also the managing and buying the loot and items.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: I was drawn to this game since the first play. It doesn't really simulate postal service, but you can relate it to some extent. What I like about this game is scattered VP all over the board, giving the player some sense of purpose. And while it's card driven, if you play it smartly, you could minimize the luck. At first I thought it's multiplayer solitaire game, since it's about racing. But the more experience you play, the more you could jerk the player after you. Wonderful.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment: I play boardgame to steer away from any game with poker cards. Go. Away!

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: A game with great strategy depth, Tigris & Euphrates really test your brain with good player interactions. Unfortunately it has theme as thick as Saint Petersburg and El Grande.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: It's a nice game about exploration and archeology. The exploring mechanism is nice, combined with area control, set collection, and action point allowance. Good combination for this kind of game.

item.name: Titan
item.comment: This is wonderful fantasy battle game. A little bit in abstraction, but nevertheless is a great game. Kinda remind you about chess but with a lot lot lot more flavor. Brilliant game design combined with beautiful theme. Kinda like playing Heroes of Might and Magic in boardgame. This is legendary work of art.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment: It's a Kingsburg lite. You roll a handfull number of dice, and the result is used to buy character card, which can be used to manipulate the dice. Your target is to get the king. The rolling and manipulating dice mechanism is quite original in my thought.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Supernatural Game
item.comment: To my surprise, this is better than Arkham Horror. At first when I read the rulebook it seemed simpler than AH. But in reality, it's more complex. More things happened in shorter amount of time. And thematically, it's better integrated. Good one.

item.name: Troyes
item.comment:
Troyes is a game about worker placement and dice management. The game relies heavily on controlled luck, which I really love. Even though there are a lot of dice rolled, the better player usually won. This is because so many things can affect the dice, and the scoring method is partially hidden. It has everything I love except one...
The theme is just a dry medieval world. But it's a good game!

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment:
This is a great game about sci-fi civilization. You get war, technology, colonizing, politics, everything you could think of. The gameplay also combination of Euro and AT, making it awesome. It's the best 4X (Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate) boardgame to date. Simulates most of everything, there are no other words beside: EPIC! This what you get inside:
- (Lots of) Variable player power - Many technologies to research, giving special abilities - Although the ship models are same, but different technologies and race power can give a very different characteristics of gameplay - Colonizing planet is one of the key to victory, but not always. Enough is the word. - Diplomacy and negotiation CAN affect your victory. - Role selection mechanics for determining phase of the game, but not strictly govern it. - Neat mechanism about action points and movement in this game.
The base game itself would rate about 2-3 (yes, really!) since it's so broken for 3+ hours game. But the expansions making it perfect. NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! Even in your 1st play.
I repeat: NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment:
2 Player Game
Incredibly delicious!! is my response to this awesome game. I was appalled by the theme and artwork. But after learning to play it, my eyes are now open. It's truly wonderful mechanism of dance in politics. And it's all governed by cards.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment: Worker placement with time management (means if you want some action, you need to select that action couple turns ahead). It's nice twist to worker placement, though I'm having a hard time not to perceive this as JA(S)E.

item.name: Ubongo
item.comment: For a party game, this much I can give. It means it's a good party game, and when I really want a filler, this game can fill it. It stretches your spatial thinking to the max.

item.name: Ultimate Werewolf: Inquisition
item.comment: At first it feels like more strategic game than normal werewolf. It's not. It drags more, and feels more hopeless

item.name: Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition
item.comment: A fun party game. And with so many roles, if I ever need party games, this is the one.

item.name: Universal Fighting System: Street Fighter
item.comment: Overall, it's a unique fighting system. But somehow, it fail to deliver it elegantly. The constant checking is exhausting, what should be fast paced battle system became boringly slow. For TCG, World of Warcraft is still the best.

item.name: Vasco da Gama
item.comment:
It's a nice twist for worker placement mechanism. As usual, worker placement are used to fill slot of available actions, but additional from that, you also need to determine the timing when the said actions will be resolved.
The thing is, it's somehow chaotic during the nature of randomization. You could have strategies, but you need to cross your finger for that. A nice break from heavy analytical games. But not too brain burning.

item.name: Villa Paletti
item.comment: A careful game like jenga, where you need to take pillars from below and put it on top. Careful not to fall it over!

item.name: War of the Ring (first edition)
item.comment:
2 Player Game
It is the best game to date that could create the moment in Lord of the Rings world. Almost everything has their own mechanism. An Epic game, and it's great especially with 2 players. Very high replayability with tons of strategies on each game.

item.name: War of the Ring: Battles of the Third Age
item.comment:
Usually I don't record playing with expansions. But since BoTA brings its own game, I'll rate it by that. The combat is a little bit more complex, and many other mechanics shifted a little, but basically it plays like WotR. Unfortunately, with almost same amount of time, and less epic story (only one episode, two towers or return of the king).
So while it is a good game, I'll prefer the original game (even without expansion) anytime. BUT, with BoTA, the original game really improves a LOT! The rating here The rating here should be 10 with the base game.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment: As a LCG, this game is surprisingly good. It has quite same level of good CCGs like Magic and World of Warcraft. It does have quite a new fresh mechanic, but blended in with the theme. The artowrk is awesome, and the deck building seems quite fun. Will need a lot of play to see if it's balanced.

item.name: Warmachine
item.comment: This game is surprisingly good. The amount of strategy depth about how to design your army, the possibilities and characteristics of armies and powers make this game very unique. I like the gameplay, and I like that the number of miniatures is fewer than warhammer.

item.name: Wealth of Nations
item.comment: The game is about economic and industry. It's easy to understand the rules, but it's not really easy to understand the game. It has very unintuitive game flow. Contrary to other games, it has a lot of options at the beginning but very little options at the end. Confusing. But it's still nice brain burning game.

item.name: Werewolf
item.comment: Fun, but ultimate edition is ultimately better

item.name: World of Warcraft Miniatures Game
item.comment: It's a solid miniatures game. Not too complex, but not too simple either. Warmachine is still better, but it's nice to have streamlined version of that. And also, the customization of the skills is what make this game fun.

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Adventure Game
item.comment: It's nice. Kinda like Arkham Horror but competitive, not co-operative. But I could see I won't playing this often. The replayability is not that great. Maybe it's due to the lack variety of characters.

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Boardgame
item.comment: I kinda like it, if I don't think that this is an adventure game. That's it! That's all you need to enjoy the game. Think of it as DOTA, not Warcraft, or think of it as Wargame, not adventure game, only you don't move an army but a character. You will enjoy this much much better. To this date, this is the best character customization ever in boardgame

item.name: World Without End
item.comment: This game is great for bullying you. But still giving you a lot decision to make. I have a sense like playing In the Year of the Dragon for the first time. The mechanic is quite novel too. But in the end, it feels like just another euro.

item.name: Ys
item.comment: I thought it was an eurogame before I played it, but reality bites. Totally abstract, like St. Petersburg. But the mechanic interraction is quite nice. Everything has meaning.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: The game is about set collection, in which I usually hate. So it's no surprise the game got little love from me. But I admit that this is quite good gateway game.
